161922900.review:
Has potential to become a good game. But at this stage (April 2024), after all these hours of gameplay (190 hrs), I got frustrated by the constant resource farming and the lack of PvE content. 

On PvP rush server I spend half of my game time, there was a setup of extra resources gathered, but it is pvp-stressful experience and the game is not oriented on defensive-base-building that I would like. By the time I had a decent base setup, a group of 3 end-level players would definitely manage to rade it because of equipment and no advanced base-defense game mechanics... Actually, the pvp is diminished into a top-down competitive shooter with resource rush-gathering and tech-tree crafting elements.

On PvE server, the gameplay was more to my type of preference. You can design an nice-looking village base, BUT there is no need for base protection or defense walls etc, since no Environment Elements (monsters etc) are going to attack it. The exploration and 'points of interest' elements are REALY minimal (especially compared to other craft-survival games), and the only actual goal is to collect the resources to advance the build and technology tree. ... But the farming needed at the official servers settings is TOO much for me. And running around the map just to gather the same thing over and over and over got me fed up... 

So, after hundred of hours I am quitting the game feeling more frustrated than fulfilled/entertained. (Lots of my game-play time was during me sleeping on the keyboard.)

BUT, I recommend the game, since it will offer you a lot of hours of satisfaction at start-to-mid gameplay, and if you are fun of PvE opportunities you could find a nice gem of a game on Cryofall. Just take note that if I was to start playing the game again, I would start a private server with boosted resource gathering and stack-limit parameters.

106312285.review:
Cryofall is an excellent game as long as you understand what it *is* compared to what it is not. This game is a season based multiplayer game where you build and construct a base camp with the intent of eventually building a rocket to escape the planet. It is not a game that is designed to be played "sandbox" forever like Minecraft, it's not procedural generated like Factorio. It's a persistent map for the season then a wipe comes and you do it again starting from zero.

Each season last 6 weeks since that's about the amount of time a player needs to get to the very end of everything and have nothing left to do. There are 20 different skills that your character learns over the course of the game and as you level them up you become *better* at doing the task the skill is related to.  You use the exp you get (known as Learning Points) in order to advance through the tech tree and branch out into various different subsets of technology. From the ability to construct more technologically advanced crafting stations to being able to create better weapons and armor, to being able to build up your own farm and cook the crops into meals that provide subtle stat bonuses to building vehicles to get around the world faster to finally building Mechs to take down the event bosses that spawn every 5-6 hours.  At first you'll have to pick and choose what you want to branch into but eventually you'll know everything and can do it all.

There are various events that happen which can be like mini contests even on PvE servers in order to get bonus loot to make your character stronger in spite of not having certain technologies. There are also enemy based events where rare mobs spawn that provide even rarer loot to finally having the event bosses where you'll need to group up with other players in order to bring them down for the rarest of all the items to make the best mech in the game as well as get the ingredients you need to complete your rocket.



As a side note I find that people who dislike this game do not understand the origins of the game therefore compare it to games that it has similarities to rather than comparing it to what it actually *is*. This game was originally designed as a season based PvP game. 

And while they created a separate PvE version of the game but,  they had to add/subtract/adjust  the content of the game as PvE plays entirely different from PvP.  They ended up adding in the event "bosses" as a means of end game challenge for those players as well as a the means to build the rocket to provide a "conclusion" to the game in spite of the fact that there really wasn't meant to be one. 

In the beginning they only wiped the PvE servers during a major patch update but, as they approached version 1.0 they settled on a 6 week server wipe for that as well as by the time you get that far in the interest in the game drops off exponentially as it becomes a situation where you have a stockpile of resources but no use for them. A game with nothing to do it in it is going to have a massive player drop off so the server wipes are a way of allow the game to maintain a state of 'freshness' to it without getting stale.

Finally, after all of that was complete they decided on creating single player servers where the player can adjust the game how they see fit to play solo even though the game isn't designed around solo game play and is in fact crippled *if* you play it that way. 

TL:DR

Cryofall is a good multiplayer game that was literally designed with PvP in mind. If you play it in any other way your mileage and enjoyment will vary the further you go away from the original premise of the game.

116305706.review:
This is a PvE review, I am not a PvP player and played on an exclusively PvE server. Very fun game if you like gathering, crafting, building, and hunting unearthly mobs. The tech trees are deep and complex, and the logistics of keeping your power grid up and running while finding new sources of fuel, armor and weaponry are very engaging. The battles are hard, the armor seems weak and you will take a lot of damage just by being touched by mobs, so you spend a lot of time just avoiding them. Aggro radius is wide, so there are no stealthy, sneak up and attack tactics, you just engage or run a lot. 

My wife and I have been playing for about 60 hours now and are just getting into Tier IV (out of V tiers) tech, so we have some way to go still for the "endgame". I've read complaints about there being nothing to do in PvE, which is certainly not true, there is plenty if you take it as intended and make your way methodically through the tech tree. Some players do it in a day and then complain that there's nothing left to do, but we've taken our time and enjoyed every minute of the progression, so take those complaints with a grain of salt, unless you're a rusher, too.

The progression is too fast, the Learning Points (LP) you get for virtually any activity come in way too fast, and you wind up investing in technology that you won't use for a long time. I'd rather enjoy unlocking things after some work, rather than wondering where to spend all my points on things I don't even yet understand. They need to slow down LP generation.

Overall, very fun game and we are enjoying it a lot more than Craftopia (which is where we came from most recently). Highly recommended for those who like what I've described above.

The game is kind of a hidden gem for sure, but it feels like an unfinished game, you know?

I will name a few things that seem to be missing.

1: The vehicles only have 2 types of flying board and 2 types of giant robots. In which the robots have a storage system for you to explore and store resources, after all the map is quite large. But where is a slightly larger variety of vehicles? For example, a motorcycle, car, among others that would fit the theme very well.

2: A simple item rotation system. Too bad not being able to simply turn an item, workbench, furnace, anything you want, to some different position for the aesthetics of your construction to be optimal.

3: Lacks a bit of variety in enemies across the map. With such a big map, it could have more diversity. There are about 20 monsters or so and everything else is almost a copy with a slightly different design or a different color. Almost everyone has the same play, they run after you and you shoot them during the run.

4: The defense against projectiles that equipment gives is not as useful in PvE, it seems that it was made almost exclusively for PvP, which is kind of frustrating, since many players only play PvE with few players. It should for example have some humanoid monsters with equipment and weapons and so on.

5: There are no caves, dungeons or anything remotely similar to that. Kinda bland, since any game of the same theme has these aspects.

6: Some systems do not make much sense, such as equipment repair. It could be from another method, like for example to repair a piece of equipment you need to use half the resources you would use to create a new one or something like that.

7: Equipment and items in general break very easily. For example, a specific weapon that every 2 shots loses 1% of durability, that is, with 200 shots the weapon breaks and you need to make a new one completely from scratch. You farm a lot to make a weapon that will be broken in 1 or 2 days hunting something and then you will have to farm again to make the same weapon again.

I could number other things that make it seem like they haven't been inserted yet, making the game seem unfinished, however, when asking in some forum or social network about the game, if it's abandoned and without updates or when things like that will be implemented, the developers rudely say something like "Why would I need to insert something? I disagree with you, the game is certainly complete and nothing is missing, that's why it was released. We will not make any updates, because it is a finished game "

TLDR
The game is worth the price and will give you a good time of fun, but with the "problems" of which I spoke among other problems that will be discovered with time by you, they will make you very frustrated.
A lot of potential wasted on this great game, due to a company and developers that don't give a shit about the game.

91331521.developer_response:
Just wanted to reply and clarify some of the points you raised and hopefully help a bit.

> The servers have a ton of people for a fairly small map
The map is actually quite balanced for the usual number of server slots (~200), but since the game just launched there is also a large number of demo players. It will go back to normal when launch hype calms down a bit.

> The servers lagged for me
We use absolutely best hardware available in each region and have direct line of communication with the data centers to ensure that not only server performance is top notch, but routing to various destinations as well. So, I'm afraid it might be your connection. For example, if you are using wi-fi it might introduce unnecessary jitter and ping fluctuations. If you'd like - we can help you troubleshoot the connection to be able to tell for a fact where the lag is introduced on the route between you and the server.

> this game is basically just for PvP - PvE has very little going on
Currently more than 80% of our playerbase is PvE players. And this number have been growing since the game was released in the Early Access two years ago. So, since people prefer this game mode over PvP we have been focusing mostly on adding content on PvE to benefit the most players. There is a lot of things you can do already and even more is planned.

> After playing for about 10-15min, consistently, my game went to 5fps and got stuck there, requiring restarting it
Yes, this issues was reported by a few other players and as it turned out it was related to incorrect GPU driver settings. It can be easily addressed by changing a few options in the driver menu.

Finally, I would like to say we could actually help you with most of what you mentioned above, so please don't hesitate and get in touch with us - we are always ready to help!

93850047.review:
An enjoyable game, but there are some pretty severe balance issues.

Right off, it needs to be stressed that this is a multiplayer game, "experimental local server" aside.  I played purely PvE; I have no need to join a server just to spend my leisure time with preteens mispelling racial slurs.  Other reviewers have touched on the toxic PvP playerbase.

The game is very grindy at the mid-to-end tiers.  You will spend almost every moment farming resources to repair your equipment, which degrades at a phenomenal rate.

Because the game is aimed at PvP, there's really no "base-building" in the way you might think of.  You're limited in scope, because the map is (relatively) small and there needs to be room for other players.  You can build (optional) walls, and set up your resource farming equipment inside, but really that's about it.

The biggest downside is the "decay"... a mechanic put in obviously to free up land for other players.  It makes sense to a degree, but it means that there's no setting down roots.  If you take a week off to play another game your base will be gone when you come back.  So why would you come back?  And that directly leads to:

Small player base.  The server I'm on is a ghost town.  There are TOO MANY servers, and the players are spread across all of them, PvE and PvP.

The map needs to be a LOT bigger, and there needs to be fewer servers so that more people can co-exist, hopefully with a lowered decay rate.

I realize this review is fairly critical, but at the same time I don't want to "not" recommend the game.  I wish Steam had a "Meh" option.  :)

91276550.review:
This review is just for people playing single or play with a friend. I do not have much experience with the broader MMO servers. See tips below for setting up your own private server.

Edit...As the game has progressed, I'm going to amend my review a bit. Have I gotten 15 hours of enjoyment for $13? Yes. Is this a great game though? No.
One of the things you'll start to realize is that the lack of automation makes it painful if you're playing by yourself or just with a friend. Unless you cheat in materials you'll find the inordinate amount of time you'll spend just trying to make plastic (dump canisters in, move them to the refinery etc) and especially making bullets and guns becomes a downright chore. There's no easy repair system either (you can kind of tinker two almost broken things together to get a little more life, but it's still a significant chore).

This game seems to be designed for specialization to an extent (someone makes food, someone farms ore etc) and you buy the other things people are making. That's at least how I can see this game working. Someone is a dedicated plastic man who sells plastic, someone else makes bullets etc. this model doesn't work if you're playing by yourself though.

For setting up a multiplayer server it takes a few minutes.
I'm playing on an old i5 4th gen processor and a 1660ti. Even running the server with a friend did not have a meaningful impact on the game performance.

First, go here: https://wiki.atomictorch.com/CryoFall/Server/Setup and it has the instructions as well as a link to the standalone server software.

A few extra things you'll need to know ahead of time to self-host:
1) for windows, you'll need to download .Net 5.0. You can get that here: https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet/5.0 and on the right side will be the desktop runtime (don't bother downloading with the SDK)
2) you'll need to know your external ip address (you can google "What's my IP address" and it will tell you). That's the ip address of your modem/router that faces the internet. This is the address that your friend will type in to connect to you.
3) you'll need to know your computer's internal ip address (the ip address that your computer actually has on your internal network. You can find that out by opening a command prompt and typing ipconfig)
4) you'll need some familiarity with configuring your router if you have one (the ip address to configure it is usually 192.168.1.1 or 192.168.0.1 type those into your web browser and you'll need to log in and look in the Advanced menu and read about "port forwarding". Basically port forwarding is how when someone connects to your outside ip address, your router knows to send it to your computer on the internal network. You'll forward UDP 6000 to your computer's ip address you got from the ipconfig command.
5) follow the instructions on the website
6) profit!

You don't need a computer science degree to set it up but you will have to read a bit to get things going  ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

So yeah, you may have to learn about your router, and your two different ip addresses (if you've got a local router which most people likely do). and a little bit of console commands to start a dotnet 5.0 server.

55742751.review:
Alright, I nolife'd this game, so you can trust me.

Pros:

- All mats are useful, which is great. Grind whatever you want.

- Skill leveling system, while grindy, is the absolute best thing this game has going for it.

- Building feels like you're accomplishing something, but be aware you can't rotate where you place things i.e. chests. Sounds like it won't annoy you, but it will. Trust me.

- Radiation zones are fun, raiding is fun.

- Game has a ton of potential if they make the necessary adjustments.

Cons:

- The number one problem with this game is the imbalance in grind for reward. You can grind the worst grind to raid someone (modern bombs), use tons of hours/days/weeks of mats to get into the most well defended base, and get absolutely nothing important out of it because everyone can hide their most important items (gear, weapons, bombs) in their land claim on their property. Even if you use a ton of bombs to blow up this land claim, you don't get the contents. Also, the land claim doesn't even get destroyed immediately, I think it takes like 36 hours or something. Makes raiding absolutely not worth the grind. 

I think the developers justify this by saying you can't store crafting mats in your land claim, but that doesn't matter. I'd rather grind the mats myself than pour everything into bombs and not be able to get endgame gear for it. Where is the incentive? This game needs PVP to keep people around, and I think this is what makes most players realize once you're at the very end game..there is no point. Until the land claim system is adjusted, I don't think I can recommend this game.

- EXTREMELY grindy. I don't know if you've noticed how many times i've said grind yet. Luckily for me, i'm used to grinding Korean mmos, but playing this game on a standard server is just not worth it. CryoSmall is probably the saving grace of this game, play on that server for 2x loot/learning points and at least SOME other players/activity (although you will feel alone most of the time).

- Normal official servers have a raid window, which means if you play on degenerate gamer hours (aka, late nights/early mornings), you cannot raid after midnight PST (at least on the official America server). However, you can start it right before the raid window closes and keep it open into the night as long as you smack a wall/the land claim/etc once every 10ish minutes.

- Ping is really annoying to deal with, and considering how few people play this, your best ping server can be absolutely dead with no reason to play.

- Animal/mob AI is lacking and easy to just kite creatures into walls/trees. Things stay in the same place. The game doesn't feel "alive" because of this.

- Rocks/trees/plants/etc will eat bullets when trying to shoot things. Mildly annoying when killing animals, absolutely infuriating when trying to kill another player.

- Map is the same every time. If you play on a server that wipes frequently, everyone already knows the best spots to live on and could progress faster than a first time player.

I tried, I really did, which annoys me as on paper this game should be amazing. This is a game with some excellent systems in place but finding itself heavily wrapped in a failed execution. The game looks good with a nice art style though. Unfortunately this doesn't make up for how boring it is. I'm a fan of grind games when done well, but this is just grind for grinds sake. The PvP server is slightly better in this regard in that it's sped up 5x, which really should be the normal pace to stop so many people quitting so fast.

I'll summarise this game in an easy analogy. This game has fishing. The fishing it has is the same as early 2000's WoW fishing. You click, you stare blankly for 10 seconds, you click. Despite there being a million better fishing systems since then, this is what they went for. I also don't get why the fishing splash is almost inaudible at 100% being just barely able to hear the splash, any notification from the rest of my system wakes my neighbours up 2 doors down and YT can't go any lower and still too loud?! Expand this fishing issue to everything else in the game and you understand what this game is, not good. So much so I don't even think a huge amount of Mods can resolve it. This game IS the fishing.

Weapons are boring. The crafting is the ultra dull type crafting, hold click to gather, click to craft, this covers most of the game. The amount of time you'll spend slowly trudging through the world is ridiculous to start until you get the hoverboard. Getting that pragmium solo will see you die many, many times, and have to corpse run for 20+ minutes each time, I'm sure some people find holding Shift+Direction for that long fun, but sadly that's not me. AI is the worst and doesn't even have path finding, getting stuck on anything in a straight line to you?!

Now, for the good systems in the skills and research, there's a load of rubbish. I eat some tomatoes and become nauseous for 5 mins?! Same with any fruit or veg. Now I need anti nausea meds which are just tedious to gather and craft for when you just want some raw fruit and veg. I don't remember the last time I got ill from a few tomatoes, or anyone for that matter so this just seems broken to me. Also if I'm out hunting and used "too many" meds - 4 - barely enough to fill HP back up I get medicine sick leaving me trapped in the middle of a volcano stuck between invisible heat walls for 10 minutes unable to heal hoping that mobs don't respawn as I can't move (I really don't want another corpse run at this point...). Really fun design here. I found night time is so frequent it feels like it's almost always night as it's so annoying to always need batteries or oil for, another thing you need to constantly grind. 76213116.review:
I honestly love this game. It strikes the perfect balance between PvP/raiding games such as Rust and resource management games like Factorio. 

My biggest gripe with raid/clan based games (*cough* Rust) is the fact that you can log off and when you get back on, everything is almost always gone. Offline raiding is nearly impossible in this game due to the "S.H.I.E.L.D." function, which makes your base unraidable but simultaneously unusable for when you're offline. Raids are forced to occur when at least one member of the defenders is online (or nobody in the defenders has been online in ~2 days), which creates a wonderful raiding experience. You never feel robbed in defeat, because you did the best you could, and weren't simply absent. Your base is still probably usable as it is extremely expensive and pointless to destroy machinery, and most of your direct value comes from said machinery. 

The progression feels solid, and while I believe it could use a little bit of a speed boost on the grind, it is mostly enjoyable. Ammunition is a bit expensive, and I honestly believe you should get about 50% more ammo from the resources it currently takes. I haven't been able to experience too much combat, but from what I've seen it feels fun, and being lower in tech level doesn't necessarily mean you can't win in a fight (although I can't recommend taking on a Behemoth mech with a crossbow...). People are generally not toxic, and asking for advice, even on the cutthroat PvP servers, you'll almost always get an answer.

The game is being developed very consistently, and the devs appear to be quite open to ideas and suggestions. Many features from the most recent update are ones that make the game significantly more fun and accessible.

What I'm basically trying to say is that this game has a surprisingly small playerbase for how good it is, and it's absolutely worth giving a try during the free demo. 8 hours of time is plenty to decide if you want to buy the game, which I did so at around hour 6.

78970222.review:
I really wanted to give this game a good review and the decision was very close to being a 'Yes' but sadly I cannot.  The game is very sterotypically German which means balance comes at the price of fun or "casual play" which rightfully should be the target market of any game which isn't labeled as hardcore. Trying to find that middleground without the use of difficulty settings is a relatively popular trap in which these type of games fall into and I fear Cryofall has done just that. Also, like many German games, the storyline is non-existent giving it a score of 0 for creativity. 

The demo and current price of ~£5 make this game a pretty big steal. In the time of 8 hours of demo you are going to experience some really good, albeit slightly grindy, gameplay which will probably make you want to buy the game before the demo time is over. If my review was solely based on that area of gameplay this was a pretty good. After that period though the game really falls off around the area of Tier 3 technologies. 

The tier 3 tech and beyond feels like jumping off a cliff in terms of convoluted design comprising of several "incorrect" choices of technologies to research at the very point where your your gain of 'Learning points' (currency required to purchase new tech) goes from too much to too few. Up until this point there was a semi-structured tutorial which led you to explore the map and point you towards techs and making you feel like you should just unlock everything. This is suddenly met with a collosal ramp up in quest difficulty requiring you to get a radiation suit in the Tier 3 tech tree. Problem is techs are getting gradually more expensive as you climb the tech trees and now techs require other techs in order to be researched. 

As a new player I can't help but feel I met this moment with a big sigh as I embarked on what ending up being a further 4 hours of mindless grinding/crafting to get this LP and spend it tech trees I had no immediate interest in to get this single technology to do a quest in what still feels like the tutorial. 

Right now there are simply far too many things stopping you from learning the game because if you go down a wrong path of tech you are punished massively for it, as LP takes time to acquire....a LOT of time. I have yet to mention that the servers are wiped with every major patch so your incentive to farm out all of these things right now should or is 0 as every hour you put into farming materials or LP, without learning anything new I might add, will simply be erased.  

Lastly it leads me to the decay system. Probably the most obtuse system there is and absolutely should not exist on PvE servers on such a low timer of 16 hours. I simply cannot agree to a system in which I am punished for not logging into the game. It completely removes any chance of the game being casual-friendly which is, and should be the target of any non-purposefully hardcore or elite game. I understand I can make my own server or play on a privately ran server with that option disabled but..really? There's nowhere near enough active players for this to even come into existence. It's purely a remedy to a problem that doesn't exist. The timer should be at the very least 3-5 days or just have a "delete my base and let me start over" button.

All this to say I will still actively play the game but, it falls short of a game I could recommend for play past the 8hr demo.

50316361.developer_response:
Now that the first update is out and the second update is completed and scheduled to be released at the end of May I wanted to address the points you mentioned in the cons section as I believe we were able to fix all of that.

- We have completely changed the balance of technology progression. We increased base value of retained LP (after death) as well as increasing the total value, but more importantly we removed ALL empty technology nodes making progression in the game much faster.
- Raiding has been completely changed. Basically all of the rules have been rewritten from scratch. There is now raiding window to encourage online raiding, there is less space to store items inside land claims, chests are unlocked by default and bombs damage is restored. On there other hand there is now also newbie protection to make it easier to start on already populated server and build your first base. But the biggest change is separation of PvP and PvE. These are now completely separated and players can choose which type of servers to join.
- Resource blocking has also been changed. Now there is contesting mechanic to ensure that there is actual competition rather than claiming resources based on pure luck. Plus other ways to gain access to oil and lithium have been rebalanced to make them more viable.
- Regarding the community in general, I would disagree, but even then - there are also amazing community servers that people can join. Some have regular events and many are heavily moderated to ensure positive atmosphere.
- End game has also been balanced to encourage advanced players to attack players at their own level or above. There is now simply zero reason to attack new players. Plus even the most advanced players can't get too relaxed or they will immediately lose their dominant position thanks to the new PvP balance.
- And finally the empty tech nodes - as I mentioned before we were able to completely remove them!

You can find the list of updates in the "news" section of CryoFall here and also, please just wait a little bit until the May update is released too. It should be a complete game changer! There are literally 6 pages of changes and improvements :)

UPD. We've released a new update on May 16th addressing many of the issues and cons you've mentioned. Here is also an official guide explaining the mechanics of PvP such as resources domination. It also explains the between PvP and PvE as we've just introduced PvE servers
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1741743411
Regards!

100866037.review:
This game can be described as what would happen if "Don't starve together", "Rust", and "Rim World" managed to have some sort of weird three way beautiful baby.   As such it is an overhead survival game where you start off on a planet where you can play alone, or with friends.  

Much like any other survival game you start off with nothing, aside from sticks, and build up from there.  With an end game of either escaping the planet (in the Single Player mode now added), or to progress in terms of technology, and just get to build the cool things (Multiplayer), and to kill one (Multiplayer PvP).

As referenced, the game itself has three modes currently. Single player, which you can progress through with an ultimate goal of leaving the planet if you wish, and unlocking a NG+ that keeps your stats, and starts you on a different map.   You then have PvE Multiplayer, and PvP Multiplayer.

Crafting entails everything from building a basic base, with chests and so on in the early game.  To building Nuclear Reactors, Solar Panels, Oil/Gas refineries, Mechs, heavy weapons and so on towards the end of the game.  With other features including cooking, first aid, fishing, mining, and so on.

Other than that the game also has bits in place for trading, and an economy by way of providing the ability to mint coins (that can be converted back to resources), and build vending machines for trading if folks want to go down that route.  

All in all, with this latest update I feel that I can very easily recommend this game.  In many ways due to the dev's reworking of various systems that took the excessive grind out of the crafting system (resource requirements), decay ( originally too fast), and hunger system (again too high) and brought it into line that made the game play more about playing, exploring, socializing, building, and (sometimes) killing.  As opposed to simply maintaining everything you managed to build so far!

If after all of this you are still on the fence about the game.  I would recommend checking out the Demo.   It's an eight hour thing that lets you try the game in it's entirety.  All without having to commit to making a purchase!

107739457.review:
Is it worth buying Cryofall? In short YES but...

Cryofall is a typical example of a potentially great game but poorly developed. Being a game with a strong component of base building that involves the construction of generators, refineries, objects increasingly complex, I would have expected a minimum of automation: hoppers for example to insert objects inside the machines or automatic turrets, but there is nothing of this, every single machine must be supplied by hand. In the endgame even reprocessing the materials becomes tedious.

92693737.review:
To put it simply, this game is technically complete but not ready to be a published game.

In the interest of fairness, I have not played the game as a PvP game, but given the issues the game has, I can only expect that the attraction in playing this game in PvP is the PvP, and not the game.

The basic elements of the game are sound and a lot of the ideas have good merit- 

*spending Learning Points gained by developing your way through the tech tree to advance through the tech tree makes a decent enough loop and its recursiveness helps prevent it becoming too grindy.
*The base building aspect is well developed and engaging, encouraging players to build and tweak the build how they like for both function and aesthetic.
*The progression tree is well developed and interacts well with the availability of many of the resources you can gather throughout the game map.
*The need for resources and their availability is developed well in such a way as to encourage building and managing multiple bases.
*The farming system works well at its basis for a game that is played daily but not necessarily for very long at a time, and also can work well for a game that is played for multiple hours at a time but less frequently.
*While I'm not personally a fan of some of the aesthetic elements, particularly the character design, I can see the appeal and the game for the most part provides a cohesive visual experience.

However, the game is riddled with issues that should have been ironed out before moving on from early access/open beta.

*The way progression in quests and Learning Points is tied to a wide variety of actions discourages player specialization in skill and technological development, but the sheer number of skills and level of involvement in things like base maintenance encourages players to operate as a group with specialists in the group.  This creates a strong tension or disagreement between the game's mechanics.
*The combat is overly simple, especially with AI mobs- there are functionally only three kinds of weapon (melee, projectile, projectile explosive), and there are no techniques or methods integrated to the game to make it operate on a more complex level.
*The Learning Point system provides Learning Points to spend in response to all sorts of actions- mining, fighting, crafting, eating foods, et cetera- but Learning Points are only spent gaining the ability to craft new things.  This means that play doesn't meaningfully change with advancement, particularly combined with the previous point.
*The skill system only provides progression in the form of percentage efficiency- time spent on actions, quantity of health and stamina, or amount of resources gained from resource nodes- and so doesn't meaningfully change gameplay other than the amount of time it takes to get things done and raw character endurance.


Most of all, as the player on our group PvE server who did the most base construction and management, base management is overflowing with busywork and poorly staged.  

For example, on the initial stage of running a power grid through gasoline rather than harvested coal and wood, you need to provide burnables to oil extractors and refineries to power them, jerrycans to extractors to fill, move jerrycans manually from extractors to refineries to refine the oil, provide jerrycans to the refineries to fill with gasoline and mineral oil, empty some of those jerrycans into barrels to store resources, move jerrycans from refineries to gas power plants so they can have enough gas to keep running, and pull the empty jerrycans from the gas power plants to put them in the oil extractors.

The lack of a fluid or other resource moving system means that players are constantly personally ferrying resources between buildings, especially since running any sort of resource development through the electrical grid consumes huge amounts of electricity compared to the expectable production of that resource development.



This game has a lot of potential to be good, but right now, most of that is just potential.  The systems and construction of this game suggests a promising game with some refinement early in a beta or early access cycle, but it just isn't really finished yet and certainly isn't polished.

With time and updates, I might eventually recommend this game, but right now, I would recommend against buying it except on significant sale, and even then question how much interest you actually have in playing it.

154681109.review:
TLDR: The game has a solid foundation, but what's built on top of that is pretty thin and grindy. PVP dependent. 

The good: Cryofall has a lot of potential. (Famous last words for indie games, right?) There are systems here that IF implemented well, could make for a fantastic game. The progression system is workable, and the point rewards for experiencing things makes it rewarding to explore and try different things. There's a lot to build and craft, and of course, there's multiplayer!

The bad: The game relies on that multiplayer, and more specifically the threat of PVP raids, to provide any sense of tension. If you're playing solo or coop with friends, the PVE experience is grindy...and that's about it. There's no real threat. Most all the enemies behave the exact same way. They just sit there until you get within their view range, and then they look at you. If you get closer at that point, they will start running towards you. Otherwise enemies just have different skins.  That makes for a pretty boring solo experience.  So yeah, the devs are relying on those PVP raiders to be your antagonists in this. There's also just a crazy amount of.....walking...and grinding. Also, I know they did it for multiplayer pvp again, but the whole "can only build base buildings while in the area of influence of your control point" thing really sucks, especially in solo/coop play, and really hampers creativity. Not to mention upgrading the control point only expands your influence by ONE tile in each direction. Doesn't really feel worth the investment.

Overall, if the devs tightened up the tech tree and balanced it out a bit to reward speccing in certain directions, made a big balance check to costs/speed/grindyness of things, and did a COMPLETE overhaul to the way enemies are handled, I think they'd have a winner on their hands.  As it stands, I wish I could put a "meh" instead of a thumbs down, but at the end of the day if I have to pick if it's worth the money or not as a non-PVP gamer, I'd say no.

131892481.review:
I have to say, that after fully completing everything in the game on a PvE server, I don't recommend this game for PvE and I would guess that this recommendation carries over to PvP as well, but I haven't tried it so can't comment on it. There are too many issues with the game, and it feels like the devs dropped the ball a bit on this one, because the potential is definitely there. The only reason I have the hours I do and completed the game is because I made some new friends in a server and logged in to play with them. The game itself wasn't a big draw for me.

For starters, the character/enemy art is fairly questionable. It's this weird mix of realistic and cartoony that is a bit hard to like. It only works well for the environmental art and item art, that's it. This is actually probably the single thing that actually stopped me from trying the game to begin with, just because it wasn't really hooking me in.

Next, is the actual progression. The progression system is decent overall, but there are some things that don't make a lot of sense. The weapon balancing is a bit weird, and certain endgame weapons feel a lot weaker than they should be. There are also a lot of mid-grade stepping stone type technologies that require too many resources to be worth investing in, making it so that a lot of things get ignored and unbuilt in favor of waiting to unlock the better version of it. There's also a tremendous midgame reliance on lithium, which you can only get in great quantities by building multiple lithium extractors and waiting overnight. There is no real way to meaningfully gather them in game. It feels like an artificial way to slow the pace of progress in the game.

Next, there are the boring environments and enemies. Most of the enemies you find are just reskins of one another, including snakes which are literally just a different color in each biome. This is a game set on an alien world, and they made almost no effort to come up with some interesting enemies to fight. There is barely any reason to visit the other biomes for anything other than to check some first time boxes off.

Finally, there is the lack of content. The first half of the game involves a lot of exploration of the map, but the second half of the game involves doing the same handful of map events over and over, and then repeatedly going to the desert to mine a single late game resource and kill things for LP (which you use to unlock tech). This gets extremely boring and repetitive because there is nothing else to do, and no other ways to progress the late game. There are some ruins you can explore, sure, but you barely get anything useful from them. Most of it is junk. You end up spending more time traveling by ruin hunting that doing anything useful.

[b]So, how can the devs fix this?[/b]
[olist]
[*]Settle on cartoony or realistic for the art. Balloon-shaped wolves isn't really working for the game. 
[*]Lower the cost of intermediate tech, or remove them from the game altogether. 
[*]Add multiple new resources that are required for mid game and late game progression similar to pragmium and make them exclusive to each biome in the game except for the meadows. I would also add at least one more biome. 
[*]Add 5-10 new enemies, and spread them to each biome. Each enemy should have movement and attacks that aren't just run in a straight line and melee, and half of them should present a dangerous threat and be limited to the harder biomes. These enemies should also be alien or robotic in origin, rather than random earth animals. 
[*]Ruins need to have some new unique enemies, need to be made much larger, and also need to have unique loot required for progression that you can only find in them. This will make them more interesting and give players more of a reason to make the trek to them.
[*]Add some mini-bosses to the game to fight with interesting loot drops to make them worth fighting.
[/olist]

Disclaimer: I only played PvE.

First hours are fun then it's just an endless grind. I think it's the first time I doesn't recommend a game after so much time but it's just a drug, like Cookie Clicker at this point.

Everything has durability, it takes hours to unlock stuff, your armor breaks super quickly if you die, crafting ammo is a pain (later on you'll build batteries that last longer but also breaks after some time and are super annoying to craft).

The game manage to never be rewarding. Unlocking the hoverboard is a good exemple:
- You're pretty slow and up to this you do everything on foot
- You unlock and craft a vehicle bay, craft an hoverboard -> this takes hours
- Happy ? Wait, you have to put fuel in the hoverboard. So that's another hour to craft the battery. You need salt that can only be found in the desert to do that or extract it from the ground which takes a lot of time.
- To put the fuel into the fuel cell, you need 20 fuel canisters: This step takes hours and hours as you set up a whole operation to extract oil you then veeeeeery slowly convert into fuel. It takes 33 real minutes to get enough fuel for one cell !!! Your hoverboard can have up to three.

THIS WILL EAT YOUR SOUL

Everytime you think you've advanced, you realise you've just opened a whole new world of grind.

Once you get to plastic there is a lot of waiting to the point where you'll have to stop playing and just come back later to get your loot (servers continue running when you're offline so there are points where you won't really progress anymore without waiting a few hours to come back)

While you evolve a lot and unlock tons of stuff, the gameplay will not change one bit except once you unlock drones. Even at the end game, you'll still be mining and cutting wood for hours. There is no real endgame (nor middle game), you'll still be fighting the same enemies (not variations, literraly the same: boars, wolves, snakes...) after 30+ hours. There are no dungeons and except for one or two bosses, you won't ever need co-op.

Basically a good fundation for a game but it lacks a ton of content.

66836614.review:
[h1] Short version [/h1] 
A pretty polished game for an Early Access title. PvP are pretty much a full-fledged game at this point, PvE however still needs some late game contents. Download the demo and try it for 8 hrs and judge it for yourself.

[h1] Long version [/h1] 
[b] GRAPHICS : [/b] I gotta be honest, my first impression of Cryofall is not that great. The character and animation felt kind of "cheap", like the type of designs you often sees in Freemium mobile games. There's a variety of avatar faces to choose from, but they all have the same default "idle" expression. They're by no means "ugly", just a tad bit uninspired. The environmental, structure and creature designs however, looks great. You can tell the artist puts a lot of time and effort into it, plus the character design started to grow on me after a couple of hours of gameplay. So, eh. It's alright.

[b] GAMEPLAY : [/b] An easy way to describe this game is "2D Rust". I've never played Rust before, so I can't really draw the comparison. The leveling system in this game however, kind of reminds me more of Age of Empires. You start with sticks and stones, craft tools, make better tools and advance your base, sort of like Age of Empire's progression of Stone Age > Iron Age. The leveling system is a lot deeper than what I expected, with a massive technology tree that branches out and intertwines with each other. The way to actually advance the technology however, is quite grindy once you reach the mid-stage of the game, particularly around Tier-3 (there are 4 tiers in total). The game offers enough to keep you busy, from gathering resources to hunting and foraging and farming and building....but even with all those contents you're still gonna feel the grind, especially when playing solo. My advice : Start with PvE, treat it as a long tutorial and getting use to it, once you reach T3 you're more or less prepared to enter PvP and team up with other players. 

[b] CONTENT : [/b] I'm surprised that this is an Early Access game, because in my opinion the game is pretty much ready for launch. If I really have to add what I want to see being add into the game, it's an actual campaign mode with stories and lore that would make me feel attached to the world. Late-game content is also really needed especially for solo players. Maybe some kind of boss fight, or challenging weather systems to keep the game fresh. There is a small area in the map that the developers purposely locked out from players, so I'm sure they're cooking up something for us in the future. 

[b] PLAYTIME : [/b] I got this game during early March, and in less than a month I'm already clocking in 200 hours. So I definitely got my moneys worth. Cryofall has a real time clock system, meaning that time still goes on even after you log out. Your crops will either, your food will perish, and everybody else in your server are still playing and progressing when you're not playing it. Plus, your structure will slowly disappear after a few days of inactivity, so you're almost always playing the game daily just so that you don't loose progression. This might be a burden to some players that likes to play whenever they like, but if you're on board with the gameplay loop, it's not really that hard to maintain. 

[b] PERFORMANCE : [/b] Works perfectly on my low spec 5 years old computer, little to no loading time. No complains here.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]  A highly enjoyable game with an addictive gameplay loop (if this is your type of genre), with enough content to keep you playing. Has the potential to be grindy once you reach mid to late game, but by then you've probably played long enough to get your money's worth. Download the demo, try it out yourself (preferably with friends) for 8 hours, then you'll have an idea on weather or not it's your cup of tea.

Unfortunately, this game isn't fun.

Before I get into criticising the game, I'd like to applaud the developers for making it possible to play the game the way you want to. Servers that periodically reset will not be something that casual players will be into, so single-player/your own instance that doesn't reset is a nice addition.

I think this game made a fundamental mistake of trying to build for both PvE and PvP.

It feels like PvP's complexity stems from figuring out how to position oneself in a team fight. This is well and good, but consequently, it feels like PvE suffers for it. I played this game for almost five hours and all encounters with creatures consisted of was either running away completely if the enemy is too strong, kite enemies and fire at them if I can defeat them or run after them if they're fleeing. This does not make for fun gameplay.

The AI is ridiculously simple, it will walk at you and attack you if in range and in line of sight and stop the moment you're ever so slightly behind a hill. I think I met a single enemy that had ranged attacks. No special moves.
Combat becomes as engaging as writing numbers some in a spreadsheet and then comparing them. Now, I don't know if the game continues like this, but if this is all I've been offered in 5 hours, I'm out.

My suggestions would be as follows:
Add literally any kind of mechanics to early-game so that players feel at least a little bit engaged in fighting. 
Examples:
[list]
[*] Dodge rolls and faster enemies
[*] Stances for blocking against fast attacks
[*] Enemies that lunge at you or engage you as a group by attacking with charges from different angles
[/list]
What I played did not inspire me to play more.

112216992.review:
There was a very good review by someone who wrote about what this game is and is not. So, I am not repeating what the guy has already said. 

I have read that this game was originally designed as a pvp game. I would say that is a very ambitious attempt, actually too ambitious. As a pve game, however, it does have some values. There are a lot of interesting things, say animals, alien species, plants, ... to be explored on the map. The map is fixed for every game (I suppose it is because the game was originally designed fro pvp) which limits its replayability as a pve game. The basic setting of this game is good. So, you just happen to be a survivor on a big island/planet where there are different regions, each with different fauna and flora, some tame and edible, some hostile and poisonous. You know nothing about anything, not even the map of the island. So, you basically start as a hunter-gatherer. As a pve exploration and survival game, it is undoubted interesting. 

Some people say it is a farming game. Yes, but you farm for some specific purposes. This game is quest based. Finishing a quest allows you to gain learning points to learn survival and other technologies to finish some new quests. Say, a region have high radio activities, so you need to learn the technology to get there in order to fulfill some quests that may require you to kill some mutated animals in that region. But eventually, you goal is to leave the planet.

I played like 20 hours without finishing the game as a single player, then joined one of the public pvp servers. It was brutal cause the setting was such that you already have some resources and knowledge (up to level 4 knowledge) to begin with and each farming action will give you like 10x (I actually don't know exactly) the amount at the normal setting. The worst part for an inexperienced player is that many of the pvp players are seriously experienced. Given all the pre-loaded resources, they crafted everything, especially weapons and armors, overnight. So, even though you joined a server 1 or 2 days late, you will be doomed cause there is no more farming. You basically just build your base asap and start fighting, killing, and looting. 

The pve game, however, is a lot more fun for inexperienced or less experienced players, cause you can really enjoy planning, designing, exploring, ... while learning how to play this game at your own pace. This makes me wonder why the developer wanted this game to be an online pvp game. All the commerce, decoration, ..., knowledge in the game become totally useless. Who will even attempt to farm outside your own base when you will be killed and looted right after you have finished farming? So, my guess is, you just form the largest clan and you will absolutely dominate this game. 

I have played expensive online war games before. Games like Vikings War of Clan do have wars between clans. But eventually most clans in a kingdom must cooperate because they have kvk (kingdom vs kingdom events). The pvp version of this game is just getting your clan done and building your base asap (which skipped more than 10 to 20 days of a normal pve game) and getting ready to kick other people out of this game. Kill-loot is what the pvp game is all about. 

So, my bottom line is if you play this game as a single player, buy it when it is on sale. If you like killing-looting pvp games, it is ok, but not great. There are better games out there.

64213194.review:
As a survival game, Cryofall has a much friendlier learnign curve and interface than most games of the genre. Enemies are not too difficult to kill, resources are generally abundant, and crafting is very easy.  It doesn't take too long to get into the meat of the game. However, once you do, it becomes clear that the entirety of the rest of the time you spend in this game - after the first hour or so - will be tedious grinding to learn enough LP (learning points) to progress in the tech tree, so that you can make anything cool and enjoy the game. 

There are also some asinine design decisions that block having much fun with this game. Once you create a land claim (an expandable space for your base), if  you log out anywhere except that land claim for too long, both your character and all of your items and your entire base get deleted. Ostensibly to "save space." On servers that only support about 200 people. Where there's more than enough room on the map for all of them. On top of that, the game will not stop you from making a second land claim and even makes it appear like you can have more than one active at a time. You can't. 

All advanced tech in the game - anything more than a 1940s level - takes countless hours of grinding for uncommon materials and learning points, too. You're encouraged to explore "Ruins" to find it, but actually don't do so until you are many many hours in to the game so that you can build hazmat suits. 

Pass.

101026771.review:
I have put in 140 hours with CryoFall, most of which was in Early Access. In Early Access the game was very playable and enjoyable. Once I had reached the top of the tech, I put the game aside to await the release. I recently started playing again to see how the released version compared, and although I did not see any noticeable differences (except the single player mode option), I was also pleased to see it was still very playable and enjoyable. 

The basics first – in the game you can forage, farm, craft, build, research, and fight. Not really revolutionary or original concepts. But I love these kind of games, and am always interested to see how a game can stand out with new innovations to these old concepts. 

The user interface is very easy to pick up – barely any learning curve to the game at all. Yet the game still contains enough depth to keep experienced gamers interested. The only real issue in usability that I hit was when I needed to figure out how to destroy a land claim I no longer wanted – quick search on google and the solution? Craft and use a crowbar. 

There is a fair bit of grinding in the game, but as you research newer technologies, the grinding becomes more automated or easier to accomplish. Almost every technology in the game is to “make life simpler” for the player in one way or another. I found the grinding was sufficient that researching new technologies felt gratifying and rewarding, yet not enough that it felt tedious – a very nice balance many similar games have not achieved. 

I found the tech in the research to be innovative and unique to this game, yet intuitive and easy to figure out and enjoy. 

Originally CryoFall was only online which made me cautious to try it. I have disliked many MMOs due to overcrowding, the simple inability to join certain tasks/quests due to a lack of level or experience in the game, or how the skills in many MMOs are gained on a timer instead of any meaningful reason.

As such I was originally reluctant to try CryoFall. But I was pleasantly surprised. Unlike those MMOs, Cryofall allows you to be a part of the entire game from the moment you start. You may want to get better gear before taking on some tasks, but you are not prevented from trying. In fact, I found the lack of restraints provides a natural mechanism for the forming of comradeship in the game, joining with other players to explore and take on harder tasks. In some ways it reminded me of the natural mechanism of comradeship that the old Ultima Online used (for those as old as me and remember UO).


Like any game, there are things that you may want to consider before buying:

This game is about grinding. If you don’t like grinding games, this game is not for you.

Although the research is well balanced, I found that it could have been more extensive. Once you hit the top of the research, there are some bosses to go beat which will entertain you for another hour or two, but really there isn’t much more to do in the game.

There is no filter on the chat. I was a bit surprised as it’s been ages since I’ve seen a chat in an MMO that didn’t have some kind of filtering mechanism. There is an option to not use the chat, but a great deal of the game is lost without the ability to communicate with the other players. The foul language that popped up on occasion didn’t bother me, but if foul language really annoys you, this isn’t the game for you. 

The servers are reset when a new major update is released. Everything in the world, including your character, will disappear and you’ll have to start again from scratch. The servers are not reset often, but just be aware that it does happen and you’ll lose all your progress.

To help with overcrowding the world, your bases will start to degrade after a certain period of time. Although I understand the reason behind it, it does make it tough to go on a holiday for month, or to take a break from the game without losing all of your progress.

There was a recent update which added the ability to play the game in single player mode. I have not tried it, but I think a lot of the fun in the game would be lost without the multiplayer aspect.

Overall, I found CryoFall very enjoyable and playable, and would recommend it as long as you’re ok with the above “issues”.
